text:
Delicious! This is an easy tip and makes a big difference in taste - in a medium pan over low heat, heat up the canned pumpkin puree, spices, and salt. Heating the pumpkin puree up takes out the "canned" taste of the pumpkin and melds the spices together nicely. Then, pour the mixture out into another bowl, and let it cool a bit before adding the condensed milk and eggs.  This little change makes the pumpkin taste much fresher!  My family loves this recipe, and I use a ready-made graham cracker crust, so easy and so good!

text:
This is the best pumpkin pie recipe! I get rave reviews on it every year.  I always use a ready-made graham cracker crust, and it comes out great.  One suggestion is to let the pie cool on the oven rack, because it cools more slowly that way.  If you take it out onto the kitchen counter, the filling sometimes cracks because of the cold air.

text:
Outstanding Flavor and very easy to make.  Two combinations I love.  A very sweet pie, nice appearance, and make sure to top it off with whipped cream.  This recipe is by far a 5 star!!  

Tips:  I did not use the ginger nor the nutmeg; instead I added 2 teaspoons of "McCormik's Pumpkin Pie Spice" (which includes: Cinnamon, Ginger, Nutmeg, and Allspice), along with the 1 teaspoon of cinnamon.  My wife loved it but she thought it needed more cinnamon.  So I made the next one with 2 teaspoons of cinnamon and she loved it.  If you like a lot of cinnamon, that's the way to go.  For me, I preferred 1 teaspoon, but I'd eat it either way.

Thanks EAGLE BRANDÂ®

text:
This is a very tasty, traditional pumpkin pie.  I used fresh pumpkin puree instead of canned pumpkin, which I would recommend because it is fresher and gives more texture.  Also, if you are using a homemade pie crust, I recommend you bake it a tad before adding the filling.  Otherwise, the crust will get mushy.  I cooked my pie for almost an hour (cooking time varies)and then, cooked for 15 minutes on the very bottom rack to finish the cooking of my crust while also lightly browing the top of the pie.  You end up with a perfectly spiced product, perfect with Thanksgiving and Christmas dinner (or anytime you crave it!).

text:
This recipe was awesome !!! Stick with the other reviewers tips and us 2 teaspoons of McCormick's Pumkin spice instead of ginger and nutmeg, I also added one teaspoon of cinnamon and warmed up  the spices and pumkin on the stove on low heat, cooling than adding the eggs and sweetened milk, it really made the spices meld together great like the other reviewer said to do. I have NEVER baked before and was able to make this recipe just perfect.  **TIP**- Where it says bake 35-40 minutes at 350 degrees....take my advice and try this- bake it at 350 degrees (after you've done step 1 on directions of course) Bake it at 350 degrees for 35 minutes, than turn off your oven and set your timer for 5 minutes while you let the pie sit in there, this way it will still cook for an additional few minutes while the oven is off but still hot and this way the oven will cool enough so that you can let the pie cool off on the top rack the remainder of the time. Doing this will prevent the pie from cracking when it hits the cool air of the counter when it's still very warm. I topped it off with cool wip and graham cracker crumbs, great texture....Thanks EAGLE BRAND!!!

text:
Very good pie.  I always have soggy crust so I Bake the crust a tad before putting the filling in, I also let the pie cool in the oven. 
I also like it a bit spicier so a little extra spice makes it extra well for me (I like ground cloves in mine as well). I make extra filling and overfill deeper pans and bake the extra filling in oven with the pies for that special taste for the cook.
Maple syrup also adds real nice flavor.  How I make it depends on my mood.  Often I make several and make one spicy and one not for different taste to please all.

text:
Absolutely delicious and the only recipe I ever use. I do add my own twist to this recipe, though. Firstly, I heat the canned pumpkin and spices on medium heat for a few minutes, to get rid of the canned flavor. Secondly, I use 2 teaspoons of McCormick's pumpkin pie spice, 1 teaspoon of cinnamon, and 1 tablespoon of vanilla, and 1/2 teaspoon of cardamom. I use one and a half 14 oz cans of condensed milk (I love that sweet, rich flavor - the extra condensed milk really adds an outstanding richness to this) instead of just one can, and 3 medium eggs (to compensate for the extra liquid). Even with the extra half can of milk, the filling fits in a standard 9 inch pie crust (I use a store-bought crust). I bake at 450 F for 20 minutes, and then I cover the top of the pie with aluminum foil, and then bake at 325 F for 1 hour. I then switch off the oven and let the pie cool in the oven for an hour, before I refrigerate it. Tenting with aluminum foil while baking prevents the crust from getting burnt, and letting the pie cool in the oven ensures that the top does not sink and that the center is cooked. This pie tastes best when made a day ahead and refrigerated overnight - this gives the flavors a chance to blend. I have forgotten to add salt before, and not noticed any difference. I have always received rave reviews about this - this recipe is a keeper !

text:
This is the greatest pie I ever made with fresh pumpkin.Great color, texture and taste. The sweetened condenced milk makes it the "Perfect Pumpkin Pie"! Try thawing then piercing a deep dish Pillsbury pie crust all around the side and bottom pop it on oven rack at 400 degrees for 8 min. remove & let cool. Then fill the shell and line the crust edge with strips of foil before baking. No more soggy or burnt crust!

This has always been my "go to" recipe, the best one ever.  To alleviate a soggy crust I brush with egg white before pouring in the filling.  I saw this tip on television back in the 80's.  Works on all pies, even turkey pot pie which is difficult not to be soggy.  Really works.

text:
This is the BEST pumpkin pie recipe!
I use a 10-inch KEEBLER READY GRAHAM CRUST which says on the label 
"2 Extra Servings".  This is a slightly
larger, deeper crust than the regular
9-inch so the filling all fits in perfectly without overflowing.  Also, the
trick to using a ready-made graham crust
is to place the crust in the freezer for
at least 3 hours or overnight.  Remove
from freezer just before filling and
baking.  This keeps the graham crust from
over-baking.  I place the pie on a cookie
sheet to bake and I shield the edges with
a pie crust shield.  I also add an extra
1/2 tsp. of cinnamon and 1/4 tsp. of
allspice to this recipe.  Delicious!

text:
I did bake this the full 40 minutes after I reduced the temperature.  I thought about leaving it in the oven with the door open after I turned off the heat to prevent cracking but after looking at this pie, I knew it wasn't going to crack out in the cold air of my kitchen so don't bother.  I added the spices it called for and didn't make any adjustment to the measurements - tasted great to me!  :)  Are the reviewers that are complaining about it not being sweet enough using sweetened condensed milk like the recipe calls for or are they mistakenly using evaporated milk as some other recipes call for?  This turned out with the perfect amount of sweetness in my opinion!

text:
NO NO NO! If you don't regularly bake pumpkin pies (and I don't), you would not see the flaws in this recipe!  I made the mistake of just trusting the Eagle brand name, printed it off and made two pies for Thanksgiving. 

We ended up throwing away both pies and wasting a lot of ingredients we could not really afford to waste. It baked up as a tasteless custard pie!

First flaw - this recipe uses nutmeg instead of cloves. Could be a personal preference, but I like cloves in my pumpkin pie. 

The second BIG flaw - this recipe leaves out SUGAR! You have to have sugar with canned pumpkin. I didn't taste the batter, and I wish I had - I might have been able to rescue it. When we cut into the pie and it was so bland and just plain bad, I pulled my spices to see if they were "dead"!  My spices were fine - it was this recipe! I pulled a few more pumpkin pie recipes,and quickly saw the sugar had been left out, and the change in the spices.  

AVOID this one - it was truly horrible.

text:
WOW!! This is a delicious and EASY recipe. After reading several reviews I decided to take some suggestions. I used a heaping teaspoon of pumpkin pie spice, a heaping teaspoon of cinnamon, a pinch of ground ginger, a dash of ground cloves, a 1/2 cup of light brown sugar and a teaspoon of vanilla. I also used 2 & 1/2 cups of fresh pumpkin that I pureed in the food processor until smooth. I used all the other ingredients and poured them into a graham cracker crust, and let me just say it came out so good it's even delicious without whipped cream. Thank you for a great recipe and all those helpful suggestions.

text:
Took some advice from others. Flipping perfect. My husband said it was the best he's ever had. And this was my first time making a pumpkin pie.
  First: I preheated the oven at 425. I put fork holes all through the bottom and sides of the crust. I pre-cooked the crust for exactly 10 minutes. I mixed the one can pumpkin, 2 eggs, 1 can sweetened condensed milk (YOU DO NOT NEED SUGAR.) The sweetened condensed milk IS the sweetener. I mixed 1 tsp. salt, 2 tsp.pumpkin pie spice and 2 tsp. Cinnamon. Then poured the mixture in the pre cooked shell and cooked 15 minutes at 425 as stated. Then covered my crust edges with foil, lowered the oven temp to 350 as directed and cooked another 30-35 minutes. If you have a big beautiful bubble, it's usually ready to pull out. Perfect non soggy crust, excellent spice ratio and thank goodness I didn't add the sugar. I love sweet and fattening but sugar is not needed at ALL in this. Excellent Pie. I will never buy or use any other recipe. It's perfect. Thanks for all the reviews and insights everyone.

text:
Only 4 stars because I feel it is lacking some spices. I use this recipe and always incease the ginger to 1 teaspoon, add in 1/2 teaspoon of allsprice and 1/4 teaspoon of ground cloves. These changes make a world of difference. I throw all the ingredients into a stock pot and heat it over medium for about 5-10 minutes before pouring into the shells. This cuts baking time by about 15 minutes and saves your pie crust edges from getting burned!

text:
WONDERFUL!  And SO easy!  I whipped this up in one bowl in 5 minutes and poured it into a store bought crust and in to the oven it went!  Some other reviews said they thought it wasn't sweet at all with out adding extra sugar. I found this to be VERY sweet with the use of the sweetened condensed milk, and believe me I am a sugar addict so I would add more sugar if necessary!  I suggest tasting a spoonful of the batter before adding extra sugar so it won't become too overwhelming. I did add an extra tsp of cinnamon and it was perfect!!!  Happy Thanksgiving to all you bakers out there!

text:
Excellent pie. Got a tip from a pie cooking demonstration a couple of years ago to eliminate soggy pie.
Coat pie crust with egg white before filling, it will act as a barrier and pie crust won't be soggy.

text:
This recipe is absolutely delicious! I made one small change - instead of a pie crust, I combined 1/2 stick of unsalted butter (melted and cooled) with 3/4 C. graham cracker crumbs, 1/4 C. firmly packed light brown sugar, 1/4 C. granulated sugar and 1/2 C. finely chopped pecans. Press the mixture into the pie plate all the way up the sides and chill for 1 hour before adding the pumpkin filling. My husband loves the graham cracker crust better than the pie!

text:
This is basically the recipe from the McCormick pumpkin pie spice label, except that they call for 1 tablespoon of pumpkin pie spice instead of all the individual spices. I've made it this way for a few years, and it always comes out great! Keep an eye on your crust (edges) so it doesn't get too brown, and always place your pie on a cookie sheet to bake--just in case of bubble-over.

text:
#1 PROBLEM w/ this recipe = It wasn't sweet enough....

It's a good pie and a great start, but every pumpkin pie I've ever eaten has been sweet (go figure...it's a pie~).  This pie wasn't even close to as sweet as I think it should be.  Therefore, I recommend the pie (especially if you're cooking it for an older crowd) but if you like your PP sweet, or the crowd is a bit younger.... I'd definitely recommend adding a 1/4cup of light brown sugar and a 1/4 cup of white sugar to it (if you look at other PP recipes, most of them have 3/4 cup of sugar so even more would be okay).
Goodluck

text:
Perfect! I put 2 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice plus 1 Â½ tsp. ground cinnamon in place of the spice mixtures. I also added a 1/2 cup of light brown sugar to the pumpkin pie mix. I used, âGrandmaâs Secret Pie Crust,â from this site. I must mention this is a nice and flaky crust but not crumbly. The filling is smooth, creamy, rich- a perfect amount pumpkin pie filling with the right amount of spices. This was easy to prepare and nicely sweetened. I covered and protected the crust loosely with aluminum foil right before baking then remove it in 20 minutes before the pie was done! It was an outstanding flavor and the warm spices blended together nicely. I baked the pie at 425 degrees for 15 minutes, then lowered the temperature to 350 degrees for 35 minutes, then turned off the oven and let it sit for 5 minutes to let the pie cool down along with the oven. I let it chill for a while in the refrigerator before slicing. I topped it off with fresh homemade whipped topping. Using both the sweetened condensed milk and combination of spices was definitely a winner. The pie crust was also a hit! A wonderful way to end a huge Thanksgiving meal!

text:
My pie ended up looking store bought! Nobody believed me!  I used a sugar pumpkin that I bought at the pumpkin patch instead of canned pumpkin.  It was easier to prepare than I thought and the kids loved preparing it. Remove stem, cut the pumpkin in half & discard the seeds and stringy pulp. Brush some oil onto the edges and place face down in a roasting pan. Add 1 cup of water and bake at 350 for 60-90 mins until tender (test with a fork). Once the baked pumpkin has cooled, scoop out the flesh and puree or mash it.  Line a sieve or colander with 2 coffee filters and let puree drain for at least 2 hours or overnight.  If the recipe calls for a 15oz can of pumpkin, that is equal to 1 3/4 cup of puree.  I got a little more than 2 cups of puree out of a normal size sugar pumpkin (not enough for 2 pies).

WOW! The best Pumpkin Pie recipe EVER, hands down! I followed some other reviewerâs suggestions for a more perfect pie: I pre-baked the crust while the oven was pre-heating; I heated up the canned pumpkin, spices and salt in a medium sauce pan over low heat, and also added 1/4 teaspoon ground cloves. After I let that cool a little I added the condensed milk and eggs and whipped 'til smooth. What a great treat. Will make again and again!

text:
I have made this pie many times now. These pies are devoured by all who try them. I followed the recipe to the letter with the exception of the pumpkin. I used FRESH ROASTED PUMPKIN and pressed the mixture through a sieve before adding it to the pie pan. the roasted pumpkin recipe is here at this site also. It couldn't be easier and is so worth it. Cut a pie pumpkin (small ones) in half. Scoop out the goo. Lay face down on cookie sheet. Cover with foil. Bake for 60 to 90 minutes at 375. cool completely. Cut away any dark brown bits. Pumpkin is done when it can be scooped easily from shells. Puree in blender before adding other ingredients. You will never go back to the can. I also read somewhere that most canned pumpkin is actually 82% butternut squash.

This recipe turned out PERFECT!!! I went through and took bits of advice from many reviewers.I used real pumpkin that had been purred. I didn't have pumpkin pie spice so I used 2tsp of all-spice and 2 tsp of cinnamon. I also added some vanilla (I never measure out vanilla). I used a ready made graham crust which was the perfect thickness and complimented the pie perfectly. I took others advice on cooking times and baked for 15 mins at 425F and then 35 mins at 350F then I left it in the oven after turning it off for 5 mins. This pie was better than any store bought pie, probably better than any pie, I have EVER tasted! I LOVED this pie and will definitly make it again...soon!

text:
I have been making this recipe for years rave reviews. I make a few minor modifications by way of increasing the cinnamon and ginger. I also mix in a little cinnamon and sugar to the dry crust ingredients to liven up the crust a bit. Also, for those of you who were complaining of a soggy crust bottom, you may want to try a trick my Grandma taught me years ago: after placing your uncooked pie crust in the pan, trim and flute the edge. Then take a dinner or salad fork and place multiple fork pricks all around the side and bottom of pan. It comes out perfectly done and if you have not over handled it, perfectly flaky every time.

text:
I tried this recipe for Thanksgiving this year since every year my family ends up running out of time and rushing to the store to by a pie.  This time I told them I would just make one.  I personally don't like pie in general, but several people that do told me it was great!  Also, for those of you who don't know this trick yet when making pies....when you have to cover the edge to keep it from burning, the easiest way is to actually cut a circle out of tin foil (use your pan to measure before filling it with pie filling).  You want it about an inch wide and then you can just slip it off and on!  No more strips to mess with!  Just a tip when you're baking this holiday!

text:
I've tried TONS of pumpkin pie recipes, ranging from Libby's to one's using coconut milk & cardamom, but they were never quite right, even with tweaks to the recipes. I wanted a custardy, smooth as silk, light textured pie, and I FINALLY have that in this recipe, with a couple changes. The first time I made this, exactly to the directions, it was tasty, but heavy.

Some tweaks I highly encourage: I doubled the recipe (for two pies), added an extra egg (for more lightness & more custardy texture), doubled the spices b/c we like lots of flavor, added some fresh ginger (maybe 1/4 tsp), and ground cloves. Then we carefully monitored the baking & made sure not to overbake it. Amazing pie, equally as good as my MIL's (the pie we compare all pumpkin pies to)!

text:
This pie was extremely creamy. I used a blue hubbard squash from my garden in this recipe. I'm surprised at all of the rave reviews for this recipe after trying it myself.  The condensed milk was so sickeningly sweet, that it is all you taste in this recipe. I added 1/4 tsp clove and allspice to this , and thankfully it came out tastier than i think it would have, had i not. I think people who rate this a 5 don't really know what a real pumpkin pie should taste like. This pie recipe lacks spice and proper flavor, and is just way to sweet. If i were to make this again, i would only use half of the recommended sweetened condensed milk.

userID:
3778502
Display Name:
HottKoko81
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
18
favoritesCount:
610
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/361419.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for Thanksgiving--Never made a homemade pumpkin pie before, and this was really simple!  I even made a crust from scratch (shortening free recipe):  1 1/4 cups all-purpose flour, plus extra for rolling 1 cup (1 stick or 4 oz) unsalted butter, very-cold, cut into 1/2 inch cubes 1/2 tsp salt 1/2 tsp sugar 2 to 4 Tbsp ice water Cut butter into 1/2" cubes freeze for 15-60 min. (the longer the better). Combine flour, salt, & sugar in a food processor. Add butter & pulse 5-10 times, until mix resembles coarse meal, with pea size pieces of butter. Add ice water 1 Tbsp at a time, pulsing until mixture just begins to clump together. If you pinch some of the crumbly dough and it holds together, it's ready.  Place dough in a mound on a clean surface.  Knead the dough just enough to form into a 3/4"-1" thick disc; do not over-knead. You should be able to see little bits of butter in the dough--those are what will allow the resulting crust to be flaky. Sprinkle a little flour around the disc and wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate at least 1 hour, and up to 2 days. Remove disc from fridge and let it sit at room temp. for 5-10 min. Roll out with a rolling pin on a lightly floured surface to a 12-inch circle; about 1/8 of an inch thick.  Carefully place onto a 9-inch pie plate. Gently press the pie dough down so that it lines the bottom and sides of the pie plate.  Trim excess dough with kitchen scissors along edge of the pie dish. Fill with pumpkin filling & bake!

text:
This is so easy and affordable to make!  I grew up eating sweet potato pie and my boyfriend really likes pumpkin pie - I never made pumpkin pie before today and he LOVES it! This beats out a store bought pie any day!  I read several reviews and decided to add extra cinnamon, 1/4 tsp of allspice, and about 2 Tbsp of brown sugar.  I warmed the pumpkin and the spices first and I used a graham cracker crust. I turned off the heat and opened the oven door after it finished baking to let the pie slowly cool in the oven so it doesn't crack on the counter.

text:
Awesome recipe.  I used to never make my own pumpkin pie (just got store bought). No more store bought for me...I am now an offical pumpkin pie snob! =) I did follow suggestions from several reviews, so here are the changes I made: 1) I heated the pumpkin with the spices; 2) I added brown sugar to the heating pumpkin as well (1/4 cup); 3) Added 1 tsp. vanilla to cooled pumpkin; 4) baked for 10 minutes less than directed, turned off heat and let sit in oven for about 20 minutes (top never cracked...looked picture perfect!).  Thanks!

text:
Let me first say that I am not a big pumpkin pie fan and I liked this recipe better than anyone else who tried it.  ~~  We had 10 people over for Thanksgiving and I made 4 desserts; pumpkin pie, pecan pie, apricot cake, and cheesecake.  Not one of our guests touched the pumpkin pie and went straight for the other desserts. My husband (who adores pumpkin pie) finally had some last night and he did not care for it.  He said it was okay, the one I made last year was better (Libby's recipe) and that there wasn't much pumpkin flavor.  My mother on the other hand said it tasted too bland, just like pumpkin from a can! I personally liked the texture of this one and may try to add more spices and maybe use canned pumpkin pie filling.

country:
None
text:
I made this yesterday with a couple of modifications, it was delicious!  I used a 796ml can of pumpkin puree to make 2 pies.  I added 3 eggs and one can of low fat condensed milk (that's what I had).  I warmed the puree first as per others suggestions, and used 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice and a bit of cinnamon, rather than what the recipe called for. I also baked the pie crust for 6 mins before adding the filling.  My pies turned out wonderful!  Perfectly sweet and light.  I will definitely use regular fat condensed milk next time to compare.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have always been a fan of the Libby's pumpkin pie recipe, but I live in Japan, and the evaporated milk that the recipe and just about all pumpkin pie recipes call for is pretty hard to find here.  They do have sweetened condensed milk in all the supermarkets however, so that is why this recipe appealed to me.  I used kabocha (Japanese pumpkin) instead of the canned pumpkin.  My kabocha was 2 lbs and produced about 2 cups of puree. I also added 1/4 tsp cloves, and I baked the pie in a ready made graham cracker crust.  It turned out great!  I will definitely make this a few more times while kabocha is still in season.

text:
This pumpkin pie isn't as thick as I'm used to. In fact, it's more like pumpkin "mousse." However, the flavor is absolutely outstanding!!! I always double the amount of cinnamon because I like the extra warmth it gives off. The ginger gives it that perfect amount of spiciness that everyone notices but no one can guess what it is. No need for pumpkin spice here! To prevent it from cracking, I always cool my pie in the oven with the door open - this is very important! Serve with whip cream, and everyone will be begging for more!

Oh wow!! This is the ONLY pumpkin pie recipe I use! I had never tried pumpkin pie before, so I decided to try this recipe. I used another person's suggestion and used 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice and 2 tsp cinnamon, but that's all I changed. I place a baking sheet in the oven while it's preheating, so by the time I place the pie on the sheet, it's hot enough to cook the bottom of the crust evenly. This is absolutely delicious!!

text:
I rate this recipe 5-stars for how easy it was to make.  I don't eat pumpkin pie, but my family rates this 5-stars for great taste/consistency.  In fact, after my husband tried this pie, he turned into a pumpkin pie snob!  I've never seen him turn down *any* pumpkin pie, but he let a store-bought pumpkin pie turn into a shriveled lump in our fridge; he refused to eat it.  I guess this was a good pie!  UPDATE (2008/12/31): I made this again for Xmas, and since my mom hinted later, after Thanksgiving, that it wasn't as sweet as she was expecting, I followed a user review suggestion and added 1/4 c. brown sugar to the pumpkin and heated it with the spices.  She RAVED, so I think I'll keep the brown sugar addition.

text:
I made two pies, one the way I usually do (with evaporated milk and sugar instead of the condensed milk)and this one.  I totally expected this recipe to taste the best, considering all the favorable reviews.  I was really surprised when the traditional recipe tasted WAY better than this recipe.  It was much smoother, better texture and better flavor. One thing this recipe is lacking is cloves, which I think really gives pumpkin pie a good flavor.  It wasn't just me, though.  I gave 6 people pieces of each and EVERYONE thought the traditional pie was much better. Very disappointed in this recipe.

text:
This Pumpkin Pie was awesome!  I used a Ready-made graham crust as many have suggested.  Make sure to cook it the full time.  My first pie looked a little brown so I cooked the second pie for 10 minutes less.  It turned out the first pie was perfect and the second pie was runny.  It's not gonna burn so cook it the full time!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good standard pumkin pie recipe. I have a convection oven and baked it at 425 for only 10 minutes instead of 15 then I turned the oven to 350 coverd the edges of the crust with foil to keep it from overbrowning then  baked for 25 minutes instead of the standard 35 to 40. I used a homade crust. I grated 2/3 of a teaspoon of fresh nutmeg and used 1 1/3 teaspoons of cinnamon This pie had more volume and set up with a more dense texture than most Pumkin Pie recipes it is quick and easy.

If "perfect" means "the pie you remember mom making" this is it. It is the traditional pumpkin pie. Very easy to make and the pumpkin pie eaters at our Thanksgiving said it was good. I used 1 tsp cinnamon and 1 tsp pumpkin pie spice and I think the seasoning was just right that way. The reviewers who said they had to add extra spices to suit their tastes must like their pie *really* spicy (or maybe their spices aren't fresh?).

text:
I made this pie using the low fat sweetened condensed milk. I also baked a regular pumpkin pie using evaporated milk. The regular pie was good; this pie was outstanding. I was baking them the day before Thanksgiving at lunchtime. The kids were home from high school and college and begged for a slice, warm out of the oven. Even my son who isn't a huge pumpkin pie fan took a big piece. There wasn't any of this one left for the next day! I really liked the idea of not having to add additional sugar to it. I did add a bit more pie spice as suggested. It's a new favorite now.

text:
Nice thick creamy texture pie.
I didn't have nutmeg, so I added about 1/4 tsp. cloves. and I upped the cinnamon to 1 1/2 tsp.
Also my crust started to brown a little to much so next time I will foil the edges. 
My family loved the pie. I thought it was alright... better than other recipes I've tried. But I had a slice after it was chilled in the fridge overnight, and now I think this is a keeper recipe. Next time I'll also add more cinnamon and perhaps pumpkin pie spice. =)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such an easy and great recipe. I saw someone comment the suggestion of heating the pumpkin up in a saucepan with the spices to rid the pumpkin of that "can taste". Totally worked! While that mixture cooled in my freezer I prepared the crust. I also mixed the eggs and the sweetened condensed milk together before I mixed it in with the pumpkin/spice mixture. I added 1/4 teaspoon ground cloves. I opted to use pillsbury premade refrigerated crusts due to lack of food processor and time. My mom was kind enough to give me the tip to fold foil over the edges of the crust to avoid burning or overcooking.

madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
43
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1203475.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a pastry chef, this is a very good recipe.  Sure it is not my own, but it is good non the less.  To those that complained it was not sweet, or more like quiche, I am making an educated guess that you used condensed milk, not sweetened condensed milk, the two are not the same, and it does make a difference.  And you must use 100% pure pumpkin, not a can of pumpkin pie filling, again there is a difference. And as for spice, always make sure your spices are fresh, not a year old, spices do go stale and lose taste within a month of opening them and exposing them to air.  Hope my tips help.

country:
None
text:
For all those negative reviewers out there that complain there is no sugar in the pie, that's what the sweetened condensed milk is for. No, this pie is not very sweet, it actually showcases pumpkin, not sugar. I will say I do tweak the recipe slightly, only because I like LOTS of spice in my pie. I double just about everything except the nutmeg and I add plenty of cloves, to me it just isn't pumpkin pie without cloves. For those who complained that the pie is grainy, you didn't beat the ingredients together thoroughly. Same with the people who said a skin formed on top. You really have to beat the heck out of this but when you do it's a great pie.

Display Name:
Megan'sCookies

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1362066.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed other reviews and cooked the pumpkin, salt and spices on low heat for a few minutes before adding the eggs and condensed milk. Instead of ginger and nutmeg, I used 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice, and I increased the cinnamon to 2 tsp. Prebaked my crust for 5 minutes, added filling and baked at 350 for 35 minutes. Once the edges were set and the middle jiggled slightly, I turned the oven off and let the pie cool with the door held open slightly with a wooden spoon. This prevents the top from cracking and gives the filling a silky texture. Served with homemade pumpkin spice whipped cream. Perfect!

text:
This is by far the best pumpkin pie recipe ever.  Very easy to make.  The only change I make is to use fresh pumpkin.  Once the pumpkin is cooked I let it sit over night and then drain about half the water.  It gives the pie a more creamy texture and isn't as heavy.  Wrap the pie in freezer paper and foil and the pie freezes well.  I have made this recipe for years and have received only rave reviews.

For me, this was just the thing because this is THE MOST delicious pumpkin pie I've ever had!

An absolutely FABULOUS pumpkin pie! It's the only recipe I've used since I discovered it back in 2001 or so. It is NOT a typical custard-type pumpkin pie, so it's very nontraditional there. But the pumpkin flavor comes through so very well, and it sets beautifully every time! I typically make 20 at Thanksgiving and Christmas; 3 for our family, plus 17 for my co-workers' tables, at their request! YUM!

text:
Hands down, the best pumpkin pie I've ever had!  I make it with the gingersnap crust from the "Gingersnap Pumpkin Pie" recipe on this site (adding an additional Tbl of butter to the crust, and omitting the sugar).  If using that crust, one tip is to pour the filling almost all the way to the edge, that way, not so much crust is showing (the molasses in the cookies makes the crust look burned, although it isn't).  Wow!  Thanks for the recipe!

I was anxious to try this because of all the high ratings. I thought it was very good, but it was just a little different than the traditional Libby's recipe I always bake. I decided to have a taste test with all of the family since I made both. The children and the grandchildren all had many comments, but in the end, Libby's traditional recipe, that's been on the side of the can for many, many years, won hands down. Eagle Brand is a wonderful product and I use it in much of my baking, and I love it. As far as the Thanksgiving Pumpkin Pie they all voted for pie marked "B" This was still a wonderful pie, so thank you Eagle Brand!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/341761.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Mmmmmm, I don't think I'm ever going to even try another recipe for pumpkin pie. This was delicious and everybody kept asking for more although they were absolutely stuffed from our Thanksgiving feast =P I followed this recipe to the T except for adding a tad extra cinnamon and a pinch of ground all spice. I baked this at 218C for 15 minutes, and then at 175C for the next 33 minutes. I used Mauigirl's recipe of '$2000.00 Pie Crust Recipe', to make my pie crust. It's a fool proof recipe that compliments this pie very well. Thanks are also due to the reviewer who gave the tip on heating the canned puree before using it to avoid a tinny or canny taste.

text:
As written, the pie does not have nearly enough flavor. I tasted it before adding the eggs, and it was so... blah. SO, I added two additional teaspoons of cinnamon. The flavor was great. However, the pie was very DRY and almost gritty as if I had used ricotta cheese. Maybe that's because I used extra cinnamon? I honestly can't see 2 tsp of cinnamon absorbing THAT much moisture, though.

On the other hand, my boyfriend said it was the best pie he's ever had, but as a pumpkin pie lover and a seasoned baker, I will definitely not be making this again. I'll definitely be going back to the old sugar and evaporated milk recipe.

text:
Awesome recipe. I followed it to the letter and it is delicious! I made both this pie and the Libby's Pumpkin Pie at the same time to compare and I liked this one better. It has a great creamy smooth flavor without being overwhelmed by spices. If you like a more spiced flavored pie, try the Libby's, which is also very good. Also, I used a smallish pie pan and so had leftover filling. I added a small amount of flour (maybe a tsp) and then poured into a two cupcake tins and removed them from the baking process about 15 mins from the end. They were awesome also!

country:
None
text:
Prebaked piecrust WARNING! I am a little new to baking pies but I wanted to share "the wrong way to do it"...I read the reviews and wanted to prebake the piecrust (homemade basic pie crust), however i did not know how long/temp to do it so I put it in the oven at temp the pie was to bake at...and for 5 min. The sides pulled down, the crust shrunk,bubbles.. it wasn't ruined...but it wasn't pretty anymore. If I were to do it again, I think I would poke holes all over the crust with a fork, only bake it as the temp is rising to 425, and for only a minute or two while watching it. Other than that...I like pumpkin pie with cloves so I added 1/4 teaspoon ground cloves and it was still fantastic!

text:
This is the first time I have reviewed a recipe on allrecipes.  My mother is the real cook in our family and usually makes every meal from scratch.  On Thanksgiving, the only things that are purchased are the ham and the pumpkin pie.  I have no idea why she buys that pie because she makes all the other desserts from scratch.  However, this year, I decided to take it upon myself to make a pumpkin pie and I stumbled across this recipe and read many of the reviews first.  I like to bake more than cook so I was excited about trying this recipe (although I do not eat pumpkin pie.)

Well, I sure am glad I read the reviews and made a few changes because my family LOVED this pie.  Even my two year old loved it and we all know how picky a two year old can be!!!  The changes I made were I substituted 2 teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice and 2 teaspoons of cinnamon for all the spices and then I added a 1/4 cup of brown sugar and 1 teaspoon of vanilla. I used a deep dish pre-made crust and made sure I forked the bottom and covered the sides with foil to keep it from burning.  It came out beautiful!  My father raved for hours...and he is not the "raving" kind!  My husband made his homemade whipped cream so I am sure that helped.  You will NOT be disappointed with this pie!

text:
I used fresh pumpkin from a medium sugar pumpkin, which came to about 4 cups of pumpkin.  So I doubled the recipe to match, except for the condensed milk - one can of the fat-free variety was sweet enough.  Two cans would've been overkill/diabetes-inducing.  I also used homemade pie crust, which I pre-baked prior to use.  Great!  Also note that 1 tsp of pumpkin pie spice is 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ginger, 1/4 tsp nutmeg.  So using pumpkin pie spice instead of the recommended spices is really no change; they're the same spices.

text:
Excellent! I added an extra TSP of cinnamon and a 1/4 TSP of ground cloves for a more spiced flavor, and it was perfect. I baked in a store-bought graham cracker crust, and it took just about 40 minutes at 350F to be finished. I had some dark splotches on the top of the pie, but they tasted fine and weren't hard at all. I checked the pie at 35 minutes and the center had not yet set, so I don't think I could have put it in for less time. This will be my go-to recipe for years to come. Thanks!

This pie absolutely lives up to its name! I have tried many pumpkin and sweet potato pie recipes, and this one outshines them all. I placed a small piece of aluminum foil around the edges before baking to prevent burned crust. **Make sure to follow the directions exactly and bake at 425 for ONLY 15 min. before reducing heat to 350. I forgot one of the times I made these and the result was a disaster.**

text:
This is a very good pumpkin pie recipe. However, I made some personal changes to make it better! I love a thick creamy texture to it, so I always blend all my ingredients in the blender before filling the pie shell. I cut the sweetness almost in half by using a half a can of condensed milk (or doubling the recipe!) and adding a few tablespoons of sugar. I also cut the nutmeg in half, the ginger down a little bit, and added a bit more cinnamon (I don't like a heavily spiced pie). Delicious!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1167743.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What's great about this recipe is that it's KID FRIENDLY.  The condensed milk creates a thicker filling for the pie than evaporated milk, so the filling doesn't slosh around when you try to put it into the oven.  I use this recipe anytime I'm cooking with my nieces.  I can't tell you how many times the filling spilled all over the inside of my hot oven when I used evaporated milk instead.

To really spruce it up, I add an extra teaspoon of cinnamon, plus a 1/2 teaspoon of ground cloves and a 1/4 cup of brandy or cognac.  I also melt 2 tablespoons of unsalted butter with 2 tablespoons of dark brown sugar and swirl the mixture into the top of the pie filling before baking.  This gives the pie a spectacular aesthetic value!

I am giving the recipe "as is" a 4 star rating.  I made a few changes (based upon a pumpkin bread recipe) and would give the pumpkin pie using the changes a 5 star rating.  I started by using a graham cracker crust and then changed/added the following spices: 1/4 tsp cloves and 1/4 tsp nutmeg, plus I used evaporated milk ( instead of sweetened condensed milk..as I didn't have any) and added 1/2 cup white granulated sugar and 1/4 cup brown sugar.  Came out delicious!!!

text:
This was the first pumpkin pie I ever made, and everyone was so enthusiastic about the wonderful creamy texture and taste. It is so easy to make and is a sure winner! Wished I had made two at the same time because it went so fast. I used Libby's canned pumpkin for a no hassle already cooked pumpkin puree. What's also divine with this pumpkin pie recipe is a graham cracker crust. Use any recipe and add one beaten egg white to the mixture for a better holding together. I didn't have to pre-back the crust because the whole thing can go in the oven and bake together. Highly recomment this recipe. Super yum.

I should have given it 5 stars but since only my husband tried it, I'm giving it four.  This was the first pumpkin pie I had ever made and the night before making this, my aunt, who is the equivalent of Martha Stewart, told me I had ruined my pie by adding Sweetened condensed milk. So I did not serve this pie to anyone even though it was beautiful!!!!  My husband then tried the pie a couple days later and said it was "Wonderful!!!"  better than the one I actually served!   Easy for my first pie too!!

This is the first pumpkin pie I have made and I found recipe is very easy although a little dry and a little bland.  I cooked the pie about 10 minutes longer than the maximum time stated as I thought that the pie was not cooked since the edges were puffed up but the center was not.  Quite likley this is the reason for it being slightly dry.  I will make this again but cook only for the time stated and increase the spices by 50%.

text:
This is a very easy recipe and it tastes amazing. This is a good place for a beginner baker to start. I just don't understand how people are making this and saying that it isn't sweet? Are you using evaporated milk instead of sweetened condensed milk? I promise you, if you follow this recipe, it will be perfectly sweet. My tips: If using a frozen crust, let it thaw and then pre bake at 400Â° for 8 minutes, let it cool, and then add the pumpkin mixture and bake according to directions. Just remember to rent the edges for the first 15 minutes. Also, I personally just add premade pumpkin pie spice until it's to my liking. I always add eggs last so I can test the batter to make sure my spices are right.

text:
My first time making pumpkin pie of any kind. I did make a few changes. I used fresh pumpkin (2 cups) and added 1/2 teaspoon of allspice. I also baked the crust first, per pie crust directions. Since I used a little more pumpkin, I had a little extra filling, so I baked it along with the pie in a separate little pan I had. That turned out great too!  My mom was worried it might be too sweet with the condensed milk, as she uses the recipe with evaporated. I went ahead with the condensed though, as I felt it would go better with the fresh pumpkin. I would make this again for sure.

text:
I made this last night to use up an opened can of pumpkin. I was brave and decided to try using my 15 ounce can minus a half cup. I put the spices and pumpkin in a saucepan for a few minutes on medium low while putting my pie crust together as another reviewer suggested.  I was in a hurry so didnât get all of the sweetened condensed milk scraped out of the can either.  I also added a bit more cinnamon than called for. This turned out great. My husband said it tasted better than the Costco pie he had at work which was a huge compliment. We tried this while it was still warm because we couldnât wait. I used half shortening and half butter in the flaky butter pie crust recipe from this site.

text:
I make this recipe regularly.  As in- once a month or more.  It is my daughters favorite dessert.  Since I have made it so often, I've tweaked it to our family's taste.  We prefer the flavor of fresh versus canned pumpkin.  So we use 15 oz fresh, which is more liquid than its canned counterpart.  I add a tablespoon of cornstarch to the pumpkin to make it less liquidy.  I also use double the amount of cinnamon and add a half teaspoon of nutmeg.  Cooking time is perfect.  I also use a graham cracker. Rust because it adds an extra crumbly sweetness factor.  We love it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My pumpkin pie turned out perfect thanks to a few suggestions from previous commenters! First of all, you're going to want to bake it at 425 degrees for 25 minutes to start with so that your crust ends up throughly cooked rather than soggy and mushy! After that, you're going to want to cover the crust with some aluminum tenting so that it doesn't burn. Once you do that, turn your oven down to 325 degrees (leave the pie in the oven the whole time) and bake for a full hour. Lastly, be sure to leave the pie, aluminum tenting and all, in the oven once you turn it off so that the difference in temperature from the oven to your kitchen doesn't cause the filling to sink or crack while cooling. Remove the tenting once you remove the pie from the oven, and allow the pie to cool to room temp before covering with wrap and placing it in the refrigerator overnight!

text:
FOOL PROOF! Let me first say that I went to culinary school, studied pastry arts, have made pumpkin pie every way known to man -- including making my own puree.   Often times, the extra work yields the best result; in my experience, that's not necessarily true for pumpkin pie. You can absolutely use fresh puree instead of canned here.  But for beginners or those crutched for time, make this. Make two. Hell, make four and freeze a couple!  
*Tips:
Like many others, I heat the puree, double the spices, and blind bake my crust first. 
Enjoy!!

Finally.  FINALLY.  A pie that looks and tastes like the kind you buy at the store, meaning the color, sweetness and texture.   (But better, because it's homemade.) None
country:
None
text:
Super easy recipe and the pie turned out so delicious! The best one I've made to date! I followed the suggestions and pre-baked my pie crust for about 8 minutes. I used Trader Joe's frozen pie crust. Very forgiving and flaky! I used a tablespoon of McCormick's pumpkin pie spice in lieu of the listed spices. It was perfect! I also warmed up the canned pumpkin and let the pie sit for 5 minutes in the oven after I turned it off. It was set perfectly! This one's a keeper for me!

I did this recipe exactly.  

Pros: recipe was easy to follow, the cook time was perfect, the consistency was great, and no cracks in pie. It was custardy, smooth, and had a great finish.

I think I actually used 14 or 14.5oz of pumpkin and used 12 mini pre-made graham cracker crusts, which was perfect for the amount of filling.  I also followed someone's suggestion of heating the mixture of pumpkin and spices to help blend all the flavors and allowing it to cool before mixing in the eggs.  I'm not sure if it made any different had I not heated the mixture prior, but it was my first pumpkin pie and it came out delicious! :)

text:
I made this for thanksgiving with a premade uncooked crust from the grocery store. I was in a rush so instead of leaving it at 425 for 15 mins then 350 for 50 mins, I left it in at 425 for 40 mins on the bottom rack. It cooked perfectly with no soggy or burnt crust but the spices which tasted awesome in the batter were a little strong for my taste when it was cooked.except for the cooking temp/ time I followed the given recipe exactly and am really glad I didn't follow the reviews and up the spices since it would have made it even worse. I also did not precook my crust or cover it with foil. I did brush some egg yolk on the crust though and it browned nicely. I will try another slice tomorrow to see if it was truly horrible or not but for now i am not a fan.

Line the pie plate with bottom pastry. Beat one egg white and 1 tablespoon water; brush over crust to keep crust from getting soggy.  Learned this tip when I was making a raspberry pie one summer.  It works great and you can use it for any type of pie.

text:
I love pumpkin pie and this was my first time making it. I doubled the recipe cause I could only find a big can of pumpkin. I've made it twice since it was so good the first time.
The first time I used half condensed milk and half evaporated. The second time I used all condensed. I much prefer half condense and half evaporated. It was too sweet with all condensed. I took the advise of other reviewers and used pumpkin pie spice but I also added more nutmeg, cinnamon and ginger.Great recipe and I'll make again next year for thanksgiving!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2322022.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my go to recipe when I don't have cream cheese to make pumpkin cheesecake, don't have enough sugar to make better recipe that uses condensed milk pumpkin pie, don't feel like hassling with either pumpkin cookies, muffins or pumpkin bread but still find myself craving something pumpkin and baked. This is easy to whip up. Instead of making a pie I pour the filling into individual serving size dishes, set them in a water bath/bake them and then serve with a plop of whip cream, Cool Whip, Jiffy Whip, Dream Whip or Marshmallow Fluff - whatever I happen to have in hand. My sons like it cooled but still the slightest bit warm with a scoop of gourmet vanilla bean ice cream on top and a little caramel topping drizzled over that along with some slices of Granny Smith apple wedges on the side to dip/use as spoons.

text:
This is the first pumpkin pie I made as my husband loves pumpkin pie and we had guest over ,Everyone liked it:) I thought it was ok,don't know what was missing but maybe it's something I did wrong.did take other suggestions and baked my pie crust for 15 mins at 375 degrees F before adding the filling and I baked the pie at 375 for 40 mins and lowered it to 325 for the next 15 minutes and the last 12 minutes I put the pies on the lowest rack and it definitely helped to give the crust a nice golden brown color.

text:
Yummy! Although I did tweak the recipe slightly. I cooked the pumpkin puree with spices on the stove and slowly added some light brown sugar until I was able to get rid of most of the bitter taste of the canned pumpkin. After I let the spiced puree cool then I added all the other ingredients. Also instead of using 2 eggs I added 1 whole egg and 3 egg yolks. Last time I cooked this pie I had a crack this time there were no cracks after cooling.

text:
This was a very easy and delicious recipe! The sweetened condensed milk was just enough "sweet" for my family. I used a 9-in deep dish ready made pie crust. I made several pies and the crust turned out the best when I let in bake in the oven for a few minutes before pouring in the batter. Similar to other reviewers, I substituted the ginger and nutmeg with Pumpkin Pie Spice. I also added 1/2 teaspoon vanilla. Finally, I used tin foil on the pie crust edges to prevent burning. I removed them about 15 minutes before the baking finished.

text:
I made my own sweetened condensed milk: 1 quart regular milk and added 1 cup sugar in sauce pan. Then simmered it on low for 2 hrs till it turned to a caramel color and the amount reduced to half. Then added 1 Tbsp butter to it, let it cool in fridge and used only "12oz" of it in the pie because it was very thin. I followed the rest of the recipe to a t. Since my  homemade Sweetened condensed milk wasn't thick like caramel-as it should have been, I had to bake it an extra 15 minutes. I was very concerned about the consistency but it turned out to be as  smooth as velvet and it tasted great! Even my 8 year old Stepson gave it 2 thumbs up!

Hi everyone,
My 8 year old son usually does not like cakes or pies but he asked me to make him a pumpkin pie and he thought this one was super delicious. I followed some suggestions as follows; I used 2 teaspoon of pumpkin spice since I did not have ginger and nutmeg, also used 2. (9 inch) unbaked pie crust. cooked over low heat pumkin and spices and for the last 5 minutes cooked at lower rack for crispier crust. before putting inside oven I covered the side crust to prevent from burning. Follow the rest per recipe. Thanks to all the suggestions & reviews This pie came out perfect and very delicious. My pies were done in 25 minutes (Instead of 35 to 40 minutes) probably cause I separated mixture into 2 pie dishes. Thank You everyone.

userID:

Display Name:
HS

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I altered this recipe to magnificent. Not from my doing, mainly from accidental or "in the moment" additions. This recipe I read as being too "condensed milky" so I decreased the amount of condensed milk by 3 oz (about a fourth of the can, slightly less). I noticed it had no added sugar and well, pumpkin pie should be delicious so I added about 1/2 cup of sugar. I noticed it had no cloves so I added 1/8th tsp (it would have been 1/4th tsp if I didn't add another 1/8th all spice!). I bumped up the nutmeg to 3/4 tsp (pumpkin pie people!) and with everything else the same it was splendid. 

An accidental part: One time a little while back when I was baking this pie, I poured too much batter into the crust (I just use the graham cracker crusts, I prefer Arrowhead Mills), so as an amateur to pies, I turned the pie into the batter mixture to pour some out. I didn't know how tough or flimsy the crust was but to my displeasure, the crust fell in with the batter and broke apart into small pieces. I beat it and used it nonetheless. It was truly magnificent. This last part may be odd but really, it worked. People in the house who normally hate pumpkin anything really thought it tasted good but still preferred not to eat pumpkin.

Thank you though, recipe maker that sold it to Eagle Brand. You created the foundation for this recipe. :))

text:
I follow this recipe exactly, it is outstanding. My advice after making this many times is to use Libby's pumpkin and the Eagle Brand condensed milk - this results in a wonderful fluffy texture. When I have used cheaper ingredients, it resulted in the bland, flat pumpkin pie you find in grocery store bakeries. I buy Wholly Wholesome organic wheat crust because it is so awesome, but I have had good luck with any crust I have tried with these ingredients.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe and I always get great reviews for it (even requests!). My only suggestion is to use real pumpkin instead of canned, and it's still very easy to do. Simply cut a pumpkin in half, remove the seeds and bake in the oven for 30-45 minutes at 375 degrees. You'll know when it is done as the outer skin gets a dark orange. Let it cool, then remove the pulp and puree with a little water. Out of 1 pumpkin, I was able to make 5 pies the first round. I froze the other half and am making the rest for Thanksgiving dinner .

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I typically don't usually like pumpkin pies, but this recipe is delicious! I roasted a 4 pound sugar pie pumpkin and pureed the innards to make the pie filling and used organic sweetened condensed milk from Trader Joe's instead of my childhood favorite Eagle Brand...The Trader Joe's version tastes like it has less sugar in it, so I didn't have any problems with sweetness. Also, I baked the pie crust for a few minutes before adding the filling...If I hadn't I think the crust would have been undercooked and soggy... Oh, and I added 1/2 tsp of allspice and 1/2 tsp of nutmeg, to give it a slightly "warmer" flavor. Everyone in the family loved it!

None
text:
Sooooo easy and sooooo yummy!  This is the only pumpkin pie I make each Thanksgiving.  I've tried making special variations like pumpkin gingerbread pie; caramel apple pie; using a non-traditional graham cracker crust - don't do it.  For Thanksgiving, you're not just baking dessert, you're recreating fond memories.  Stick with the tried and true perfect pumpkin pie & you'll hear rave reviews from your guests.  Don't skimp on the whipped cream either.  This pie deserves fresh whipping cream & it only takes a few seconds to add vanilla & whip it up with a hand mixer.  Leave the spray can and tub at the store.

text:
ABSOLUTELY WONDERFUL!!! My husband is very picky with his pumpkin pies because his birthday sometimes falls on Thanksgiving and a pumpkin pie is his birthday cake every year. Usually his sister makes him a pumpkin pie for his birthday because she uses real pumpkin, not the canned stuff, which is what I use. The only thing I did different was use 2 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice which has all the spices you need. I made 6 of these pies through out the month of November (2 to test before Thanksgiving)...They turned out perfectly every time!! My husband even said that he preferred my pumpkin pies this year over his sister's pie that she made him for his birthday!! THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR SHARING!!!

None
text:
I have been using this recipe for several years. It is so easy and scrumptious.  I always get raves and requests for the recipe.  The best pumpkin pie recipe I've encountered.  I make two very minor additions.  I add 1/4 tsp cloves and 1 tsp pure madagascar vanilla extract.  I place pecan halves around the outer rim of the pie as soon as I take it out of the oven.  Let is cool or serve barely warm with brandied whipped cream( 1 c. chilled whipping cream, 1 Tbsp. confectioners sugar and 2 tsp brandy(folded in after whipping) Sprinkle with a bit of nutmeg...Decedant!!

I'm still in search of a good homemade pumpkin pie. And I'm glad this was the trial run and not the actual Thanksgiving Pie!

text:
Excellent! I made two of these pie for Thanksgiving. I replaced the spices, except the cinnamon, with 2 tsp of Pumpkin Pie spice. As someone suggested I did add 1/2c  of light brown sugar and a touch of honey.  Your best bet is to taste the batter (I know a bad thing with raw eggs!) and if in your opinion it needs something...add it.  

Everyone raved over my pies, not a bite went to waste, and it has been requested that I make two more for Christmas.

text:
Delicious!  My 71 year old mother said this was the best pumpkin pie she'd ever tasted.  I followed the advice of some of the other reviewers and heated up the canned pumpkin and spices on low heat to get rid of the "canned" pumpkin taste.  I also baked the pie crust for 15 minutes at 350 degrees and let it cool before adding the pie filling to prevent it from getting soggy on the bottom.  This is an amazing pumpkin pie recipe!

Very easy recipe to make.  I substituted a pre-made graham cracker crust instead of a regular pie crust.  Only suggestion is to pre-bake the crust...I didn't and it turned out soggy, but the pie was still really delicious.  I would recommend pre-baking whatever crust you use to avoid sogginess if you like a crispy crust with your pie.

This is the best!!  I did howevermake changes, especially after reading other reviews- I like a less spicy pie and some vanilla- I only used the teas. of cinnamon and not the other spices- I added a little brown sugar and a little white sugar- also a tablespoon of vanilla- I know that sounds like a lot but my pie was without a doubt the best pumpkin pie we had ever tasted--  I baked until you could tell at a glance that it was set- and used my crust covers to keep my crust perfect!  My husband's favorite is pumpkin pie and he was bragging to everyone about my pie!!  Easy even for a beginner!!

text:
The flavors of this pumpkin pie are great! I didn't rate it a 5 because I found it to be just a bit sweet for our tastes. I also just made the custard rather than as a pie (to cut calories). I made the filling and poured it into a 1qt corning ware dish put that in a baking pan in a hot water bath (surrounded by about 1 inch of warm water) and baked it at 325 for 45ish minutes! I've also tried the same recipe using evaporated milk instead of the condensed milk and adding 3 tab. sugar...very tasty and less caloric!!

text:
I took the advice of others and heated the pumpkin and spices. The only other thing I changed was to add a quarter teaspoon of allspice and a teaspoon of vanilla to the filling.  The filling is thick (easier to get into the oven without sloshing), but be aware that if the surface is uneven when it goes into the oven, it probably won't smooth out much while baking.  Mine wasn't picture perfect, but no one seemed to care!

This is one of the better pumpkin pie recipes.  I baked it about 10 minutes or so longer than the recipe called for. It's nice to have just the right amount of spices in a pumpkin pie (in my opinion too many bakers over-spice their pies) and using the sweetned condensed milk gave the pie a richer flavor. My mom said it was better than hers! The pie lasted about 20 minutes.

text:
I agree that this could use more spices, BUT I liked that it tasted like pumpkin and not a mouth full of spices. I like the texture created when using sweetened condensed milk better than when using evaporated milk. It also makes it not as liquid, so it's easier to get into the oven without spilling! I'll be using this recipe from now on just pumping up the spices a tiny bit.

text:
This is the recipe I found on the web when I was trying my first pumpkin pie, it was on a different site and called Magic Pumpkin Pie. When I made it I had no idea that traditionally evaporated milk is used. When I tasted it, I thought it really was magic because it tasted SO much better than the average pumpkin pie. It's a lot more fattening too, but sometimes you just have to splurge and this recipe makes it worth it. The sweetened condensed milk makes a much smoother, denser, more decadent pie and elimates the need to add suger, it is perfectly sweetened, sometimes the recipe makes too much for a store bought pie crust. I microwave the leftovers for 1 min. and eat them warm out of the bowl, yum!

text:
This is a traditional pumpkin pie recipe. Although it turned out perfectly, one thing I will say is that it tasted basically like every pumpkin pie I've ever had, which is a good thing and a bad thing. I like my desserts to stand out above the rest, and this just tasted like your standard, run-of-the-mill pumpkin pie. Which, we all know pumpkin pies are GREAT, but I prefer something a little different when serving food to guests. I'd like them to be able to tell my cooking and frozen pie / Kroger bakery cooking apart.  =] I did use the pumpkin pie spice in lieu  of all the individual spices and it turned out fine. I probably will make again, but I'll find something else to take with it. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Pumpkin pie shouldn't be hard... and this recipe is NOT!  So easy!  This was the first time I made a pumpkin pie (Grandma use to do it) and I decided to bake is right after the turkey came out of the oven.  When we were ready to have dessert the pie was still warm (I've always eaten it cool) and I preferred it, especially with cold Cool Whip on top.  YUM!  The only thing I might do differently is add a pinch more of all the spices - but not too much more.

Delicious! I followed the recipe exactly and didn't change one thing and it came out perfect. I don't know why people have said it was bland because I believe it was far from bland, in fact I thought it may have been to spicy until after it was cooled for a few hours in the fridge and it turned out perfect. A few people in my husbands family claimed they never liked pumpkin pie but helped themselves to seconds on this one. I also brought an extra pie to my Husbands precent on Thanksgiving night and all the cops were licking their plates clean looking for more!! This recipe will be our traditional pumpkin pie every Thanksgiving and Christmas!

text:
I made this pie for Thanksgiving, and I amazed myself as well as my family.  It turned out perfectly.  It looked dense, but tasted light and airy.  The amount of spices were perfect.  I know for a fact that I'm terrible at making pie crusts, so I cheated and used a frozen pie crust from Pillsbury - the kind that come in a box, and you just roll them out.  I got creative with the leftover dough cut from around the edges, so I made a decorative crust that looked like leaves, all the way around.  It was really the most beautiful pie I've ever made, I even took a picture!  Topped with fresh whipped cream, this recipe was to die for!

text:
Very good basic recipe for pumpkin pie.  The can of condensed milk makes it sweet enough without all the hassle of measuring sugar; just open can and pour.  I noted the comments of others and baked this pie for the minimum baking period; I might bake a little longer next time in my oven.  Felt the the filling never fully came together in the baking process but maybe just me being critical.  Definitely increase the spices if you prefer a spicier pie; I used 2 tsp. of fresh (this is important---spices only last so long) pumpking pie spice and 1 1/2 tsps. cinnamon.

text:
VERY YUMMY!!  Deffinatly the PERFECT pumpkin pie!!!  This recipie will replace my old recipie for now on!! My whole family raved over it!  The Condensed Milk made a big difference in the texture of the pie which was nice and thick and rich!  MUCH better then recipies with the evaporated milk!  It cooked easier and I didn't have to "recook" when the center was runny like i have had to do each time with the evaporated milk!  Be sure to get a DEEP dish pie shell or be prepared with a SECOND pie dish!

text:
Absolutely divine!!  My son is a pumpkin pie lover (10y.o.).  He loves the filling/custard, not the crust.  What I have started doing is adding a 1/2 to 1 cup of biscuit mix to the filling and pouring it all into a pyrex dish.  It gives the filling a more bread pudding texture, but it still has a wonderful pumpkin pie flavor.  I used 2 cups fresh cooked pumpkin with this recipe and 1 cup biscuit mix.  I let my son make/mix it up and he was "doubly" proud of his creation.  All we needed extra was a dollop of whip cream!

text:
I improvised quite a bit with this recipe and followed a few suggestions. I used a Graham cracker crust. I also heated up the pumkin sauce with some water for about 5 minutes on a low simmer, added the salt and spice, and heated that for a few more minutes. I then cooled it a bit in the freezer, added the milk and eggs, and added more salt and spice till I was satisfied with the taste. Then, put that on 350F for about 35-45 minutes. And refrigerated it to cool it some. It was a hit!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie was amazing. It was my first attempt making a pie and it turned out perfect! I did mesh a bunch of the suggestions together. I used 1.5 cans of pumpkin puree and heated it with spices on the stove before adding the sweet condensed milk and eggs.  I used all the spices, plus added some pumpkin spice seasoning and cinnamon. I just kept adding to taste while heating on the stove. The sweetened condensed milk made the pie plenty sweet. I used a frozen pie crust, allowed it to thaw as instructions on package suggested, used a fork to poke holes throughout pie crust, and baked the crust for 10 minutes before adding the filling. And tented foil while baking to prevent crust from burning. Beyond pleased with the results!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made 7 of these and the first had an error that ruined it. But it  was purely my fault... I used Evaporated Milk instead of Sweetened condensed milk. It was a pretty looking but bland mess.

 You do not need to add sugar as the condensed milk is plenty sweet. 

 Another person overcooked their pie and blamed it on the recipe and this is just wrong... two cooking temps and if you do not lower to 350 when advised it will burn.

 You can be a bit flexible with the recipe and it's pretty rugged.  

 I used 3 medium eggs instead of 2 large and it came out fluffier.

 You will want to be sure to blend properly or you may get patches of seasoning...

My pie did rise slightly but it came down as I cooled it  and I used a non traditional pie crust... Graham cracker pre filled from the dollar store.

 You won't want to over bake or the crust can get hard... 

I will add 4 pix at the end if it will let me.

text:
Super easy, very quick, and really good. As some others suggested, I used 2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice and about 1.5 tsp of cinnamon. I did not use the nutmeg. I heated the pumpkin & spices on very low heat, let it cool then added the sweetened condensed milk and eggs. Mixed together and poured into the shell. First time I used a premade pie shell which I did NOT prebake, just egg washed, and the other time I used the 9in Graham cracker crust. I liked to Graham cracker crust the best.

I thought this was a delicious pie! I did make a few changes, though. First, definitely warm up the pumpkin purÃ©e and spices in a separate pot to really mix the flavors and to help get rid of the canned taste. I also recommend making your own pie crust. I made a simple flour, butter, spices crust and it turned out perfectly! Also, with the crust, I would pre-bake for at least 10 minutes. I also added an extra teaspoon of cinnamon for some extra flavor. I also made a homemade whipped cream with heavy cream, sugar, cinnamon, clove, ginger, nutmeg, and a little bit of vanilla extract. It was the perfect touch!

text:
Awesome pumpkin pie! I always doctor up any recipe plus I wanted to make two pies so hereâs the changes that I made: 
30 oz canned pumpkin
1 can Eagle Brand milk
3 eggs
4 tsp pumpkin spice
2 tsp cinnamon
1 tsp vanilla extract
1/2 C brown sugar
1 tsp salt
Prepped by warming the pumpkin and spices as per other suggestions. And then baked at 425 for 15 minutes, then 350 for 30 minutes. I then turned the oven off and left the pies on the rack for an additional 10 minutes. Enjoy!

text:
I add 1/2 teaspoon of ground cloves and slow heat everything in a pot over low-medium heat until everything is liquefied. Pour promptly into pie crust and bake normally.

I find that this removes the metal can taste and reflects that fresh cooked pumpkin taste.

Display Name:
Joe Tairei
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used egg whites instead of whole eggs (a carton of organic "365" brand from Whole Foods):  1/3 cup plus 1 TB = 2 large eggs, so I used 1/3 cup egg whites, then added one whole egg to get the yolk in there.  I whipped the egg whites, then added the condensed sweetened milk, then added the other ingredients.  I also used a pumpkin, rather than a can of pumpkin puree, and it turned out more liquidy and a much larger batch.  I filled two pie crusts with it, and the pies came out DELICIOUS.  Even the teenager was licking her chops (of course, I also supplied whipped cream and ice cream to sweeten the deal).  This was a great recipe and will go in my permanent file!  There's nothing else quite like pumpkin pie.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe, but I used unsweetened coconut cream due to an allergy. Cooked the coconut cream with 2/3 c sugar, 1 tsp vanilla, and a pinch of salt. Then, using other reviewers' suggestions, cooked the pumpkin and spices together, let cool, then mixed in eggs. Mine needed a longer cook time to properly set, but was delicious. Note, I also added 1/4 tsp Allspice to the pumpkin mixture with the other spices. My kids loved it and requested me to make another!

region:

country:
None
text:
My husband is a huge pumpkin pie aficionado,  and to deviate from his "preferred" recipe is to invite disaster!  That being said, I didn't have any evaporated milk on hand yesterday so I came across this recipe and figured I would give it a go.  I must admit that I changed the spices a bit because - like some other posters - I like my pumpkin pie with cloves, nutmeg and allspice in the mix, along with the cinnamon and ginger.  Otherwise, I left it like it's written.  It was a HUGE hit with my husband, who never noticed any lack of sweetness or complained about texture.  In fact, he RAVED over the pie!  I cooked it per instructions, however, my pie was done MUCH sooner than the recommended time, so I removed it to my counter (I live on the coast of Ecuador and it's just beginning summer here, so no worries about "cold air" cracking the top!)  I did use fresh pumpkin that I steamed, we don't have anything like canned pumpkin here!  Anyhow - it's a huge success and now my go-to pie recipe!

Lydia Louise Alexander

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6014636.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I Asked the Community for tips on baking the pie in a store-bought graham cracker crust and followed Bookie's advice to bake at 400 for 10 minutes, then at 350 for 40 to 45 minutes. It turned out beautifully.

The 5 minute in-oven cool down that a couple of reviewers recommended helped the pie finish setting without cracking. I already knew to pour the mixture into the crust already on a baking sheet on the oven rack.

I doubled the spices, added 1/4 tsp. cloves and a few drops of vanilla (same amount of salt). I whisked it all together by hand

I didn't expect the crust to turn out crunchy, so people who are going for that with a graham cracker crust should stick with a no-bake recipe rather than this one.
Review:

5

After reading the other reviews, used 3 teaspoons of a homemade pumpkin spice recipe and added an additional teaspoon of cinnamon. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Happy Thanksgiving everyone! I have almost  always used this recipe. It is tried and true and comes together very quickly. I used a ready-made Pillsbury pie crust this year; the kind you unroll into your own pie plate. It did take a bit longer to bake to have the center set - around 12 extra minutes. The only change I made was to add 1/4 tsp of finely ground black pepper to the spice mix. That's the latest "secret ingredient" for pumpkin desserts  around here. It doesn't make it peppery at all. If you have ever had black Chai tea, that also has black pepper in it but you can't taste it really. No, it doesn't give the pie any sort of chai taste, just some added depth of sweet-spiced flavor. If you like a spicier, quite sweet pumpkin pie, this is your recipe, especially if you add just that little pinch of pepper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this Pumpkin Pie and used this recipe for 3+ years now, and will never go back to any other!  I love that it's sweet and rich enough for me to add the extra spices that I enjoy without overpowering the pumpkin flavor.  I do add 1tsp vanilla, and my own spin on the spices is; 2tsp McCormick Pumpkin Pie Spice, 2tsp cinnamon, 1/4tsp nutmeg, and 1tsp allspice. I also always sprinkle the bottom of the crust with a dusting of powdered sugar before adding the mixture to prevent a soggy crust. I got that tip from another reviewer years ago from this website and it has been foolproof for me ever since!

text:
I made the pie using a frozen pie crust from Trader Joe's that I defrosted and put into a 9" pie pan (unbaked and chilled).  I followed the advice of others and warmed up the canned pumpkin, spices and salt.  Then I cooled the mixture in a bowl and added the cond milk and eggs.  It was quite yummy!  Make sure to serve it with some fresh real whipped cream!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1374769.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very simple and easy pie recipe. I made this, but I started with a fresh organic pie pumpkin. My son wanted pumpkin seeds to I reserved them for him, cut the pumpkin into large chunks, rubbed them with a bit of olive oil, salt , pepper, and roasted it in the oven. I had to wait until the next day to bake, because I didn't have condensed milk. (Generic version from Aldi worked just fine.) The next day I mashed the peeled chilled pumpkin chunks with the condensed milk, 2 eggs, nutmeg, and cinnamon. (I didn't have any ginger.) I used an immersion blender on the mix after mashing it together, poured the puree into a Gluten Free Graham Cracker Crust, and baked it according to instructions until a wooden skewer came out clean.
THIS IS THE BEST PUMPKIN PIE I HAVE EVER TASTED!!!

text:
OMG I don't even like pumpkin pie that much and this was the best I've ever tasted! I did make my own pumpkin puree from fresh pumpkin so I don't know if that's what made it better, but it was fabulous! Instead of the spices I used 2 tsp pumpkin spice and 1 heaping tsp cinnamon. I also used a Graham cracker crust. I followed step one then baked for 35 minutes at 350 and let it cool 5 minutes in the oven with the door open. I made this for my husband's Italian family who asked me to make "the American pumpkin dessert" and they all loved it! I will definitely make this again and always use fresh pumpkin (they don't sell  canned pumpkin here anyway). I made some fresh whipped cream to add a dollop to each slice

text:
Did you know that cans of Eagle Brand sweetened condensed milk from Canada are smaller than those sold in the US? I didn't, until I was just about to mix up the ingredients and went to convert the can's millileters to the recipe's ounces, juuuust to be sure I had it right. The 300ml variant sold in Canada is about 10oz. I wasn't about to make the trek to the grocery store for 4oz of the white nectar, but at the same time, it was not a significant amount to omit. To make up for lost volume, I increased the amount of pumpkin by about .2 cups, added a couple tablespoons of white sugar as well as a generous splash of whole milk.
The baking process was straightforward but I left it in the oven nearly 10 minutes past the recommended baking time to achieve optimal jiggly-ness.
Having strayed from the recipe, I was worried about the end result. Those worries were unfounded and I got rave reviews for the pie. Some people said it was the best pumpkin pie they have ever tasted. 
So, why only four stars? Because the millileter volume of the condensed milk needs to be declared, and I think the "jiggle test" needs to be mentioned as a method of determining doneness. If I had taken it out when the knife came out clean, it would have been underdone in the centre.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-10-07T04:21:56.533
helpfulCount:
0

This is the only pumpkin pie recipe I will use. Been over 10 years and its still the pie Im asked to bring to every event. TIP I add a bit more of the spices because we like to kick it up a notch...I tried all spice and pumpkin pie spices but we  still  like it better when we mix our own spices. #loveeaglebrand #eaglebrandfan
