text:
A tip to get the filling perfectly cooked (without cracks) is to cook the pie until it is about 85% done, then turn off the oven, and open the door a little to let it cool down while it finishes cooking. I did 15 mins at 425, 30 mins at 350, then turned off and cracked the door open. The pie filling was perfectly cooked and did NOT crack! Beautiful presentation. Pour into an un-cooked pie crust.

text:
An excellent recipe- and truly, the condensed milk method is far superior to the evaporated milk and/or gelatin methods. The texture is much better and the recipe doesn't suffer from the addition of brown sugar. I make this with a gluten free shell. My boyfriend typically hates pumpkin pie. I have come to make this regularly with a half-jar of Nutella swirled in just after filling with the pumpkin mixture. A crumbled, spiced hazelnut topping makes this pumpkin pie go from kitsch to elegant with almost zero effort. I'll never make pumpkin pie without hazelnut again.

text:
Instead of nutmeg & ginger, use 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice w/ 1 tsp of cinnamon. I also added 1 tsp vanilla. I used fresh pumpkin & homemade whipped cream. For the cream: Just 1 cup whipping cream, 1 tsp vanilla & 2 tbsp confectioners sugar, blended until stiff. At my altitude the pie only required 30mins at 350 degrees.

text:
It is simply the perfect pumpkin pie. I have been making it for years. This recipe is right from the Eagle Brand label. I sometimes add 1 tsp vanilla extract. This pie is requested at every holiday dinner. 
Cover the last 15 minutes with pie ring or aluminum foil just the edges and the pie crust will be perfect. Test with a knife about 1" from edge and if clean then the pie is done. Cool on rack for at least an hour before cutting. You will not have any leftovers!!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-12-18T15:49:58.017
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
10675700
Display Name:
Angela Chang
isPro:
False
followersCount:
6
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
32
favoritesCount:
34
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2720254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe! I did not use Eagle Brand anything (lol) and it came out great. I followed another reviewer's tip and warmed up the pumpkin puree and spices over medium low heat. I added a tsp of vanilla, 1/2 tsp almond extract, and a tbsp of cornstarch to thicken it up a little. This gave it a really well-rounded pumpkin flavor than just spicy. I also blind baked my butter/shortening pie crust first. Then i covered the edges with foil during the final bake so it wouldn't burn. Seems like it also kept the edges of the pumpkin mix itself from overcooking as I got a nice even bake -- no sinking or bubbles. I baked at 325 degrees (low and slow for an even bake) for about an hour as well. Taking off the foil in the last 20-15 min. My pie did not crack during cooling.

text:
I would definitely recommend this recipe to someone else!  It was easy to make!  I did make a few changes.  I added 1/2 a cup of brown sugar and I also added 1/4 tsp of cloves to the recipe.  To make sure the crust did not get soggy I brushed the crust with egg whites before adding the filling.    For anyone who complained about the taste of the pumpkin pie not being sweet enough or not being able to taste the spices enough, the number one rule in baking or cooking is to make sure you taste your product before you bake it/cook it so you can fix it.  Just something to keep in mind.  Happy Baking!

text:
I used the easy pie crust by BIBMOM which was a breeze. 

For the salt, I reduced to pinch, used coconut milk (30% less ) instead of condensed milk and use the flesh of half a small pumpkin ( microwaved for 25 min ). 

The first part of the baking, I tweaked the baking to 200C at 13 minutes and did the second part at 180C for 35 minutes. Hubby was like, WOW! can we have something like this tomorrow?

So yup, it was a success. Thank you!

text:
This recipe is great! It turned out beautiful! I made a couple of changes like others have suggested. I used 2 tsp. of Pumpkin Pie Spice & 1 1/2 tsp. Cinnamon instead of the other spices. I also mixed the pumpkin with the spices and salt and warmed it on the stove before making the pie. The only other thing I did differently was that I brushed the pie crust with melted (real) butter before adding the filling to it. I've made this several times now and my husband and I absolutely love it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for my husband (who was a chef and a culinary graduate), and he absolutely loved it.  I did follow the recipe, and some of the tips.  I  cooked pumpkin, spices and salt on medium heat for a few minutes first, and also par baked the crust for 8 min. at 425 (put parchment and rice down to avoid puffing up) to ensure no soggy bottoms!  Once pumpkin was cooled off, added milk and eggs.  Then cooked at 425 for 15 min, then 350 for 37 min. and shut the oven off.  Took out an hour later.  Crust is perfect, no soggy bottom, and the pumpkin is also moose like in texture.  Husband has made thousands of pumpkin/squash pies, and he liked this the best!

What a disaster ! Grandma's pumpkin pie was the farthest thing from perfect; unless you like some sort of pleasant tasting slop in a pie shell. What a disappointment. This is not my first pie - I have made countless pies with great success. This one was an absolute disaster. Was grandma into the Brandy or liqueur when she formatted this recipe. text:
Nice and simple recipe. Loved that. I did make some key changes so that's why I couldn't give five stars. First off, my boyfriend got fresh pumpkin from the market. About a pound and a half. We boiled it out in the double boiler to soften and then we made a puree using the blender. I made the pie crust from scratch as well using this recipe http://addapinch.com/pie-crust-recipe/  and used Nestle Betty Sweetened Condensed Milk. The recipe was a good foundation though and for someone who doesn't like pumpkin, I really enjoyed how it turned out.

I made this pie for thanksgiving this year and it was amazing. People who said they don't usually care for pumpkin pie thought it was delicious and asked me to make it for christmas  as well. I followed a couple suggestions from the comments. I blind baked the pie crust (that I made from scratch) at 350Âº F for 10-15 minutes, I used fresh pumpkin, and I also mixed the pumpkin, spices, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat then added the condensed milk and egg and let it cool. The pie turned out amazingly both in looks and taste.

Very good...not sure if there is much difference between this and the Libby's recipe.  Used 2tsp pumpkin pie spice and 1 tsp cinnamon.  Prebaked the crust for 8 minutes at 400 degrees without edges covered.  Added foil around edges for entire baking time.  Set timer for final 35 minutes and left pie alone to cool in oven afterwards with oven off for 5+ minutes.

text:
Easy as pie! I followed the advice of other reviewers and heated the purÃ©e and spices and pre-baked the crust a bit before pouring the mixture in and baking it. Also I allowed the pie to cool in the oven to avoid splitting.

My pie was a hit! So much so that my dad asked me to make him another one just for him!

Oh, and a tip for those folks who said it wasn't sweet:  The recipe calls for sweetened condensed milk, not evaporated milk. There is a HUGE difference and believe me if you use sweetened condensed milk your pie will be plenty sweet enough.

I used Trader Joe's frozen pie crust which is a little difficult to use because it breaks apart but can be pressed back together...it's the best tasting pre-made pie dough I know of.  I also used 2 teaspoons of pumpkin pie spice (I used Trader Joe's brand...not sure how it compares to other brands) in place of the ginger/cinnamon/nutmeg.

I used a crown pumpkin, roasted in the oven with skin on. Once cooled, the skin peels right off! With the exception of the fresh pumpkin, I didn't change anything.  This will be my go to recipe for pumpkin pie.  The Kiwis love it too!

text:
I made the mistake of using the can of pumpkin sold in all the grocery stores at this time of year, which is 29oz. Yes, this is twice the amount of pumpkin to sweetened condensed milk. Why do they not sell a smaller amount of pumpkin in cans? Maybe so you can make two pies at the same time; maybe so I can mess up recipes like these. In any case, this means it will not be nearly as sweet. Fortunately I did double all the other spices. We'll see how it all turns out!! So I am not rating this recipe up or down since it is already a disaster. Regardless, Happy Thanksgiving all!

This is my go to recipe for pumpkin pie.   I always puree my own fresh pumpkin for this recipe.   I do add more spices than it calls for, but that's just me.   I have made these pumpkin pies for years, and I always get raved reviews.  You do not need to add sugar to this recipe, as one reviewer said.   If it needs more spices according to your taste, add it.   Who cooks or bakes anything without tasting it?  Always taste!

text:
This was my first time making a pumpkin pie completely from scratch and I couldn't have done it with out all the tips from this recipe. I made the crust from the buttery flakey pie crust recipe on this site as well. I think the biggest help for this pie was using a water bath to avoid the pie cracking. I also put foil on the edges of the crust to keep them from over baking. I may take the foil off sooner to get the crust a little more golden brown next time, but other than that the pie was perfect!

I made a few modest changes - added 1 tsp of pumpkin pie spice,  2 tbsp of maple syrup, an extra yolk, salt, and vanilla. city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Such an easy recipe!! I made my crust from scratch, but it would be fab with any crust! I followed the suggestion of others and used 2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice and 1 tsp of cinnamon instead of adding all of the other spices. In addition, I mixed the canned pumpkin and spices on the stovetop on low heat, then let that cool and added the eggs and condensed milk. Fun tip that momma taught me: when adding liquid to a mixture (like this one, or pudding, or jello) always add it in a little at a time. That way it all mixes well! I also sprinkled a little pumpkin pie spice on top! Topped it all off with homemade whipped cream. SO yummy, quick, and easy. :)

country:
None
text:
This turned out very well, with a few alternations (as per the suggestions of others). I heated the canned pumpkin with the salt and spices beforehand and let it cool prior to adding the egg and condensed milk. I also doubled the ginger, cinnamon and nutmeg, as well as added 1/2 tsp of ground cloves. Poured the whole mixture into a pre-prepared graham cracker crust and baked until it set (with the knife coming out clean). It took much longer than the recommended time, and when it was nearly set, I turned off the heat and let it cool inside the oven (to prevent cracking). Topped with light cool whip and caramel drizzle... Everyone loved it!

text:
Could be excellent with the right changes.  As it stands it is rather bland and you should add sugar and clove to the recipe.  If you want to go the extra mile and skip excess sugar try substituting a real sugar baby pumpkin (the actual kind meant to cook not the Halloween decoration type there really is a difference) cut in half, remove seeds ONLY, not pulp, coat shell with canola or vegetable  oil, and bake for approximately 45 minutes or until pulp is tender.  This will be sweet and fresh naturally, no canned pumpkin needed, continue with the regular recipe from there but try clove with the other spices.  Yummmm, turned out perfect, no "sharpie skin, no bland taste just moist sweet and delicious.

I have made this pumpkin pie recipe for the past few thanksgiving dinners and it's always a hit with most asking for the recipe.  I can never seem to find a 14oz can of the Condensed Milk, only the 10oz can.  I just use the 10oz and add extra pumpkin Puree to make up for the 4oz shortage.  I actually think it's perfect this way... not to Sweet  (which I prefer) with excellent pumpkin flavour and a hint of spices.  I will not be looking for another pumpkin pie recipe... this is definitely 'the one'.  Enjoy!!

text:
I used fresh pumpkin. I baked one medium sized pumpkin (about basketball size) 2 hours at 375. Scooped it out and drained. I weighed out the amount in the recipe, but the batter was too runny. I added 1/4 cup all purpose flour to thicken. The stringiness looked unappetizing  (my first pumpkin pie so I didn't know if that was supposed to be that way). I blended it up in a ninja for a consistent look. 

Perfect temperature recommendations. I didn't get a thick layer like one reviewer had. Moisture and texture was light and perfect. One person who ate it thought there was too much salt. I disagree, but whipped cream is the great pie equilizer. I used Pilsbury ready made crust. It was yummy!

text:
This is definitely my favorite recipe for pumpkin pie.. I also made the Libby's recipe but I prefer this one more. It spicy and sweet.. I didnt follow the recipe and listen to all other reviewers with 2tsp of pumpkin spice and 2tsp of cinnamon. TASTED REALLY GOOOD! My tip are: use eggs white to brush the crust instead of foil bc the crust sticks to the foil and hard to remove. breaks up the whole crust! egg whites makes it perfect golden and shiny. Another tip is use like 75-80% of the condense milk bc its really sweet! can hurt your throat but other than that perfect..

text:
I changed the directions a bit to bring out the flavors alittle more before baking...

1.	Whisk canned pumpkin, spices and salt in a medium bowl until smooth.
2.	Heat in a saucepan using a low heat.  Let mixture cool
3.	In a separate bowl, beat eggs and sweetened condensed milk to together
4.	After mixture has cooled, mix the pumpkin, egg and condensed milk mixture together (insuring to smooth-out the lumps) then pour mixture into pie crust

This was my first attempt at a pumpkin pie. It was great! Here In Canada condensed milk is sold in a 300ml can.. Which is just shy of 14 ounces. So I added in a splash of whipping cream to make up for the moisture. Also added in about 1 tablespoon of vanilla. I took the advice of others by heating up the Pumpkin and spices first. My can of Pumpkin was larger.. So I used almost 2 cups of puree. Used the butter Flaky pie crust recipe from this site.

None
text:
This pie recipe is easy and results are great every time. I butcher our jack-o-lanterns every year, steam the pumpkin in chunks, let it cool, hand squeeze out the excess liquids, and package in 2 cup amounts for freezing. One of these two cup packages of frozen pumpkin work perfectly for this recipe. I thaw it well and blend in the Vitamix with the other ingredients before pouring it into the crust and baking. Apart from using my own pumpkin from scratch, I follow this recipe exactly and it works out well every time.

text:
Absolutely delicious! I randomly made this pie and it turned out amazing. Every bite was mouth-watering and as I write this, I'm wanting MORE. Luckily for me, with this recipe I surprisingly had enough batter to make TWO pies!! The only changes that I made to this recipe was: (1) heating up the canned pumpkin pie and mixed in the spices/salt in a skillet over a medium heat. (2) chill the pumpkin mixture in the refrigerator until slightly firm. (3) pre-heat the pie crust for three minutes (4) pour mixture into pie crust. I will most definitely be making this recipe again!!!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2768502.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For a light, melt-in-your-mouth heavenly tasting filling-- Follow this  EASY SIMPLE WAY to make your pie extra light and silky smooth, almost like a chiffon style.
     Separate the eggs, adding the yolks to the pumpkin mixture as directed (make sure it's cooled if you heated it).  In a separate bowl, whip the egg whites until have nice firm peaks and just before you're ready to pour your pie into the crusts, GENTLY FOLD the whipped egg whites into the pumpkin mix, incorporating them completely. Then pour mixture into your waiting pie crusts. 
    Since this method makes a taller pie, you might want to use a deep dish pie tin if you have one (I use a 9 in deep dish).  The finished pie is light, airy, silky smooth and just melts in your mouth. I get more compliments when done this way vs the usual way. Try it next time-- you won't regret it!!

text:
My bf and I made this pie yesterday, and followed recipe exactly as written. We let it cool for about two hours, then tried a slice. It was wet and grainy, and flavorless. We were surprised because of all the positive reviews. Today, he decided to try another small slice to figure out what went wrong, and to our delight, it was AMAZING! We now know we sliced it too soon, and from now on will make it a day ahead of when we need it. It was so delicious, perfect consistency and the flavor was right on! Truly a Perfect Pumpkin Pie! PS-If you are searching for a simple pie crust, try the Land O Lakes Butter Pie Crust recipe. So easy and goes great with this pie.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this into 6 mini pies using  fresh home made pie dough. I also utilized the tip of heating the pumpkin with the spices and they turned out perfect. Freeze the mini pies crusts first then do 10 minutes at 425 and drop oven to 325 for an additional 20 minutes. The crust was crisp and flaky and the pie filling was smooth and 
silky! I used a fluted tart pan with a removable bottom, it helps if you have problems with the bottom of the crust not getting fully cooked.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2547616.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I'm eating this pie right now and I must say....wow!! I followed the instructions, but like many of the others, I tweaked it a bit. I added a 1/2 cup of light brown sugar, a tablespoon of vanilla, a tablespoon of pumpkin pie spice, and all of the originally listed ingredients above. 

I then poured the batter into a ready-made graham cracker crust and followed the instructions, baking it at 425 degrees for 15 minutes and then lowering it to 350, but instead of baking it for only 40 minutes, it took an hour for my pie to get done. Once I saw that it was done, I turned the oven off and let it sit in the oven for an hour so it could cool properly. 

But MAN this pie is amazing! You've got to go with graham cracker crust, too...it accents the pumpkin pie's flavor so well!!

text:
I think the people who are giving this recipe 1 star must not be using SWEETENED condensed milk, because my pie came out very sweet.  I don't like nutmeg, so I omitted that.  I also used fresh pumpkin puree from a Halloween pumpkin, and I added about a tablespoon of blackstrap molasses to darken the color and add the flavor that I loved of my grandma's pumpkin pie which was sweetened with table molasses (her recipe used evaporated milk, but I didn't have any on hand, which is why I chose this recipe instead).  It was easy came out well!  I do recommend adding the blackstrap molasses!

text:
I tried this recipe and was really excited since this was my first pumpkin pie. I followed the recipe exactly. I glad it was a test pie because it was horrible. All that I tasted was unsweetened pumpkin.  I thought I overlooked sugar but after reviewing, this recipe didn't call for any!!!! The sugar was left out of the ingredients needed and after checking out other recipes, I knew I had obviously goofed. I was just surprised that others hadn't commented over the oversight. I made another with sugar, eggs, and pumpkin pie spice added instead and my husband loved it!!!!

country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. I read the majority of the reviews and decided to follow the recipe as is. I did add 1/2 tsp ground cloves. I used a field pumpkin,(got it from the store for Halloween but never carved it.) Using fresh pumpkin, in my opinion, makes for a fluffier and lighter pie. I also made it in a graham cracker crust. The finished product was a light, fluffy, well balanced tasting pie. Other reviewers added sugar, I don't think it needed the added sugar. The sweetened condensed milk has sugar in it and if you make it with a graham cracker crust, that also has sugar in it too. I will use THIS recipe only. It's very easy to put together. This is a very good recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this recently with some changes. I used graham and a shortbread pie crust. I also used 2tsp of pumpkin pie spice and 1tsp of cinnamon instead of the spices listed (except for the salt). First pie was just the pie in the graham cracker crust. As other reviewers mentioned it did have this weird film on the top but it didn't detract from the flavor.
2nd pie, I used the shortbread crust (which I prefered), and I also added a pecan praline top to it that consisted of chopped pecans, dark corn syrup, white sugar, brown sugar, vanilla extract.
Extremely delicious!! I think by itself, the pie is just fine, but with the added sweetness of the praline top and the shortbread crust, it made this over the top yummy!

region:

country:
None
text:
One thing fun to do to taste the end result for impatient people like me is use a tablespoon of the pie filling and roll out the pie crust scraps.  Put in a bowl in the microwave for approx. 1 minute.  Yes it's not fine dining, but it gives me a taste of how awesome it's going to be, especially as I can never try it until the actual big dinner!  Fun for kids too.  Put it in the microwave for 45 seconds and keep doing in intervals of 10 seconds until filling doesn't stick to fork when poked in.
And yes this pie is amazing, I am so glad I found it!  I made two pies from this recipe by doubling it but only had one can of evaporated milk.  Just added a bit of extra sugar and it still turned out fantastic!

text:
Just made this pie tonight. Loved it! I wanted to make something quick and easy for dessert and happened to have E.D.Smith Pumpkin pie filling on hand so used that. I did not alter the recipe except to add more spices - The pie filling is spiced and very sweet (definitely taste the batter before you put the eggs in) I love ginger though, so I grated a a good big tsp in there. I added more cinnamon, nutmeg, ground cloves and all spice. 

I gave it 4 stars because it is really simple and tasty. I made a bunch of tarts too!

text:
Loved this recipe! I did add a bit more cinnamon and I used the tip about heating the pumpkin and spices prior to filling the pie shell. It really seemed to make for a smoother, richer taste in the finished pie. For years I used a recipe almost exactly like this, but it called for sugar and evaporated milk - I like this much, much better with the condensed milk and eliminating the sugar. Thanks for a super easy, super delicious pumpkin pie recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
cpbakes14

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first time ever making a pumpkin pie & it turned out perfect!  I did make a few changes.  I added 1/2 cup packed light brown sugar & used 2 tsp Cinnamon, 1 tsp Nutmeg, 1/2 tsp Ginger & 1/2 tsp Salt. (more than recipe called for).  Pre-baked the store bought crust (edges covered) for 5 minutes & then poured in filling & baked (with edges still covered) for 40 minutes until knife came out clean.  Set on counter to cool/set for 2 hours & then refrigerated.  Took out of fridge the next day (since I made this a day ahead) 1.5 - 2 hours before serving so it wasn't so cold.  Served with fresh made whipped cream!

country:
None
text:
I always go overboard when it comes to reading the reviews and then I become stuck! I was afraid of messing the pie up because I was using a fresh pie pumpkin instead of the canned stuff and I wanted it to be sweet enough. I used all of the pumpkin innards (it was exactly enough when mixed with everything else), 1 - 14oz. can sweetened condensed milk, 2 eggs (they were not large), 2 tsp. cinnamon, 2 tsp. allspice (I was not about to spend $6 on "pumpkin pie spice"), 1/2 cup brown sugar and 1/2 tsp. salt. It came out perfect. My first ever pumpkin pie. I like mine sweet, though, and it was exactly how I like it.

I make this every year with REAL pumpkin. I slice and steam our halloween pumpkins (which we only draw on, not cut). Once steamed the pumpkin is moist and the skin comes off easily. text:
Turned out "perfect" even for first-time pumpkie pie maker.  Followed suggestion by others to use 2 tsp. each of pumpkie pie spice and ground cinnamon + 1 tsp of vanilla.  After pie has baked for 30 mins. at 350 deg., I sprinkled streusel-pecan topping which I found on the Eagle Brand website with this recipe.  Doubling the recipe and using 29 oz. can of pumpkin filled up 2 deep-dish pie crusts.

text:
I'd never made pumpkin pie before (since I'm not a fan), but my step-son always lamented not having it on Thanksgiving, so I told him I'd make it if he helped. It was easy and foolproof (I realized too late that I was out of nutmeg). I used the Eagle Brand sweetened condensed milk rather than evaporated milk, and it turned out so well that I didn't mind having some (and the kids all had seconds). My step-son gives it 5 stars.

GREAT recipe!  I followed it exactly for Thanksgiving Day, and everyone loved it.  I made two pies and followed the advice of another reviewer, and switched the pies to the other oven shelf halfway through the cooking process so they would cook evenly.  I made them a day ahead and then just warmed them in the oven while we ate our main meal.  Everyone raved about them.

text:
I added 1/4 tsp ground allspice and an extra 1/4 tsp ground cinnamon, and I followed the tip to heat up the spice and pumpkin before mixing. (I did that until the mixture was very warm to the touch; it took a few hours to cool down!) The result was ABSOLUTELY DIVINE, I love this pie, so delicious! Tastes better if you leave it in the fridge overnight for the pie to firm up a bit. Great recipe!

Okay, so I changed it up a bit, but still felt the need to review it. I doubled the recipe to make 2 deep dish pies. I made it with 1/2 pumpkin puree and 1/2 sweet potato puree. I also doubled the spices (plus a little bit extra), added 1 tsp. of vanilla, 1/2 tsp. cloves. Put into pre-made deep dish pie crusts. Cover edges with foil or they'll burn! Very good pie.

text:
Very easy and very delicious recipe! This is the first time I've made pumpkin pie and it's very nice! I used a ready rolled shortcrust pastry, I recommend blind baking it first otherwise the bottom might be a bit soggy. I baked for 15 mins, then another 35 and it came out nicely. The spices are very strong btw, so if you like it a bit milder then I suggest reducing the ginger and nutmeg a tiny bit. Great recipe, great pie!

text:
I made this pie and an apple pie for Thanksgiving.  By the end of the weekend the apple pie was long gone but the pumpkin pie was barely touched.  I felt like the condensed milk overpowered the flavor of the pumpkin.  I like a strong pumpkin and spice flavor, which is probably why I do not prefer this pie.  My mother in law said she liked the heavier denser pumpkin pies, so she thought it was ok.  I will not be making this again, but to be fair, if you are like my mother in law and like the heavier denser pumpkin pies, you will probably like this.

One thing I would probably do next time I make this recipe is try to sweeten it more. I aslo would add more cinnamon, but the pie did taste good. Thankyou ^_^

text:
The is truly THE perfect pumpkin pie recipe. This was actually the first pumpkin pie to ever grace our Thanksgiving table this past year. We've had pumpkin pie before, just never on Tgiving. But I wanted to make it and it was delicious. My top wasn't smooth at all so it wasn't the most pretty pie, but that didn't affect taste. Also, I needed to put foil over the crust edges toward the end to prevent burning. But my aunt said it was the best pumpkin pie she had ever tasted. It only lasted until lunch on Friday for leftovers. This will be the recipe used from now on!

I made this pie for the first time the night before Thanksgiving, and it was really easy and delicious. I used my own pre-baked pie crust recipe. Added 3/4 cup sugar to the filling mixture and used 1/4 teas cloves instead of nutmeg. After 30 minutes in the oven, I covered the edges of my crust with tin foil, so the crust stayed nice and golden brown.

text:
Excellent!  My first time making pumpkin pie and it was so easy...prepping was so simple.  I made the pie crust and all in all, it took 15 minutes to the oven!  I can taste the nutmeg well balanced with ginger and cinnamon.  Be careful not to add too much nutmeg, it will over power all the flavor in the pie.  I love nutmeg but too much of it can taste very unpleasant.  Just follow the recipe and you'll just love it!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great pie! I absolutely loved the consistency. I also loved the graham cracker crust. Here's the combination of spices I used, and it came out to the perfect combination of spice and sweet.

-- 1 tablespoon molasses
-- 1 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon
-- 1/2 teaspoon ground ginger
-- 1 teaspoon ground nutmeg
-- 1/4 teaspoon allspice
-- 1/2 teaspoon salt
-- 1 teaspoon vanilla
-- 1 heaping teaspoon dark brown sugar

I chilled for about an hour before serving, and then garnished with maple-flavored leaf shaped cookies, as well as a sprinkle of ground cloves on top. Served with Cool Whip.

text:
this is a very yummy pie!  i normally don't like pumpkin pie...i think this one tones down the pumpkin flavor.  i did heat the pie and spices on the stove first (and oops, the condensed milk as well!) and i only used half the amount of ginger to make it less spicy for my daughter's kindergarten class.  i also used fresh grated nutmeg.  she helped me make it and loved the flavor as well.  i can't stop eating the leftovers!  sooo good even when snuck straight out of the fridge.  i don't think it needs added sugar...there is a lot of condensed milk.

None
text:
I used this recipe for my first pie ever, and it was a success! I wasn't sure how much of the spices to use, since every reviewer seemed different on their preferences, etc, but I used the 2 tsp of pumpkin pie spice and 1 tsp cinnamon that was recommended by others, and it was a tad bit too spicy for me and my mom's likings.. next time I would probably just use extra cinnamon, but that is only my preference. I used an already-made frozen pie crust. The edges were a little dark (even when I covered it with foil), and it bubbled a little on top (it dried with 'bubble' imprints). Otherwise, the consistency and taste was great. 
Very easy recipe to follow as well.

text:
I've been using this recipe for years with great reviews. Instead of "fresh" pumpkin-which is very grainy-a local farmer's market suggested I try Hubbard Squash. It's fanastic! I bake it covered with an inch of water to steam until soft; and scoop it out when cooled. 2 and 1/4 cups of the squash is substituted for pumpkin. I like a little extra cinnamon too. It makes a very creamy texture. Whipped cream a must!

text:
This was really great. I had tried another pumpkin pie recipe from this site a few days earlier and was not happy with the results. I DON'T like the souffle-like pumpkin pies, I like them dense and "set" - this recipe did it. 
I used a pre-made graham crust, added a little more cinnamon than what was called for... delicious. Top with lots of whipped cream. Just don't go overboard with the nutmeg - do exactly what it calls for and none more because you can really taste it in there.

My 12 year old daughter,13 year old niece and my sister-in-law, all loved this pie.  No leftovers here!  I did add 1 extra tsp of cinnamon, a pinch of cloves and a couple shakes of pumpkin pie spice to try to overcome the "blandness" that some people mentioned.  I thought it was a little too much, but everyone else said it was wonderful!
